title: How to Make Chickpea Chocolate Chip Cookies

steps.headline: Gather your ingredients and supplies.
steps.description: It may seem like a silly step, but if you do this first, it will save you time later and help you get everything done much more quickly. Because everything you need will be in one place, you don't need to waste time rummaging through cupboards.

steps.headline: Open the can of chickpeas and dump them into your colander or strainer.
steps.description: Rinse them well and place them into the food processor.

steps.headline: Portion out the salt carefully, baking soda, and vanilla extract.
steps.description: Do this using your measuring spoons. Then, add the ingredients to the food processor.

steps.headline: Grab your measuring cups and use the correct cups to measure out your peanut butter, milk, oats and brown sugar.
steps.description: Add these to the food processor as well. It's okay to measure out a little extra peanut butter. It sticks to the measuring cup and sometimes it's hard to get it all out.

steps.headline: Blend the ingredients until the mixture is very smooth.
steps.description: You should have roughly the same texture as regular cookie dough when you're done.

steps.headline: Empty the mixture into a mixing bowl, if you want to.
Add chocolate chips to the chickpea dough and stir until the two are evenly mixed together.
Put plastic wrap over the top of your food processor or the bowl you've moved the dough into.
steps.description: Then, place the mixture in the fridge and allow it to cool down for at least a half an hour. Often, the processor heats up and makes the dough warm, and it's much easier to make into balls for cookies when it's chilled. If you want to stop here, this makes a great edible cookie dough dip that is also gluten free!

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400°F when your dough is almost done chilling.
steps.description: Make sure you check the oven to see if anyone else has left anything inside.

steps.headline: Ready your baking sheets.
steps.description: Spray a nonstick cooking spray on them. Another option would be to grab parchment paper, cut it to the length of your baking sheet, and lay it on the top of the sheet.

steps.headline: Pull the dough out of the fridge and remove the plastic wrap.
Use a spoon to carefully roll a ball of the chickpea dough onto the cooking tray.
steps.description: Keep repeating until you run out of space on the tray or dough. Some people like to use an ice cream scoop so that every dollop is perfectly uniform. If this creates your desired cookie size, then feel free to try that.

steps.headline: Wait for the oven to heat fully.
steps.description: Carefully place the tray(s) on one of the inside racks.

steps.headline: Allow the cookies to bake at 350 degrees for 20 to 30 minutes, or until you have dark brown molasses.
steps.description: Make sure you wear oven mitts to pull the trays out.

steps.headline: Transfer the cookies carefully to a cooling rack.
steps.description: Be careful when moving the cookies. They may be hot enough to burn your skin, and sometimes they will fall apart. If you don't have cooling racks, take the cookies out five or so minutes early and allow them to cool while on the baking sheet. Be careful of this strategy! If you let the cookies bake the full 20-30 minutes, they will keep cooking while the tray is heated and may burn.

steps.headline: Let the cookies cool for at least 20 minutes.
steps.description: Then, transfer them to a plate and enjoy!

text: Gather your ingredients and supplies. It may seem like a silly step, but if you do this first, it will save you time later and help you get everything done much more quickly. Because everything you need will be in one place, you don't need to waste time rummaging through cupboards. Open the can of chickpeas and dump them into your colander or strainer. Rinse them well and place them into the food processor. Portion out the salt carefully, baking soda, and vanilla extract. Do this using your measuring spoons. Then, add the ingredients to the food processor. Grab your measuring cups and use the correct cups to measure out your peanut butter, milk, oats and brown sugar. Add these to the food processor as well. It's okay to measure out a little extra peanut butter. It sticks to the measuring cup and sometimes it's hard to get it all out. Blend the ingredients until the mixture is very smooth. You should have roughly the same texture as regular cookie dough when you're done. Empty the mixture into a mixing bowl, if you want to.  Add chocolate chips to the chickpea dough and stir until the two are evenly mixed together.  Put plastic wrap over the top of your food processor or the bowl you've moved the dough into. Then, place the mixture in the fridge and allow it to cool down for at least a half an hour. Often, the processor heats up and makes the dough warm, and it's much easier to make into balls for cookies when it's chilled. If you want to stop here, this makes a great edible cookie dough dip that is also gluten free! Preheat the oven to 400°F when your dough is almost done chilling. Make sure you check the oven to see if anyone else has left anything inside. Ready your baking sheets. Spray a nonstick cooking spray on them. Another option would be to grab parchment paper, cut it to the length of your baking sheet, and lay it on the top of the sheet. Pull the dough out of the fridge and remove the plastic wrap.  Use a spoon to carefully roll a ball of the chickpea dough onto the cooking tray. Keep repeating until you run out of space on the tray or dough. Some people like to use an ice cream scoop so that every dollop is perfectly uniform. If this creates your desired cookie size, then feel free to try that. Wait for the oven to heat fully. Carefully place the tray(s) on one of the inside racks. Allow the cookies to bake at 350 degrees for 20 to 30 minutes, or until you have dark brown molasses. Make sure you wear oven mitts to pull the trays out. Transfer the cookies carefully to a cooling rack. Be careful when moving the cookies. They may be hot enough to burn your skin, and sometimes they will fall apart. If you don't have cooling racks, take the cookies out five or so minutes early and allow them to cool while on the baking sheet. Be careful of this strategy! If you let the cookies bake the full 20-30 minutes, they will keep cooking while the tray is heated and may burn. Let the cookies cool for at least 20 minutes. Then, transfer them to a plate and enjoy!
